sourceDesc.bibl: W. H. Dean. After Rain! Molong Argus, 23 September 1898, p. 1.

projectDesc.p: Transcribed and encoded as part of Settler Literature and Environmental Change in Australia and New Zealand, Marsden Fund Standard Grant 19-MAU-022 (Te Apārangi Royal Society of New Zealand).

lg.l: Vanished has drought for again growing green
Is grass over the meadow and plain,
A glorious change in the weather has been,

Earth’s blessed with a downfall of rain. Rain. The Molong Argus reported on 19 August 1898 that rainfall has been so abundant in most districts that the soil is now thoroughly saturated (p. 4). These rains were a temporary break in the Federation Drought, which commenced in 1895 and peaked in 1901-2, and is regarded as one of the continent’s worst droughts.
Rain! and no longer from pitiless skies
Hots suns upon thirsty crops blaze.
The beauteous scenes that now gladden the eyes
Are pointing to happier days.
Green are the cornfields, apace grows the wheat,
And daily farm laborers toil
In fields that soil have been parched with the heat,
And as they turn up the rich soil
Each shining mould board, Mould board. A mouldboard plough buries existing vegetation and exposes topsoil. each sharpening share
Each time at the ends moving out
Reminds me from ploughing that every care
Has faded away with the drought.
To broad verdant flats, from the brow of each hill,
What joy does it bring unto him
Whose fattening cattle there wander at will
To waterholes full to the brim!
The tinkle of sheep bells he hears through the morn
From the paddocks where merry birds sing,
Those sheep of their fleeces in time will be shorn
And profit their owner will bring.
Vanished has care and bright days are ahead
Autumn’s labor will harvest repay,
The wheat will be carefully placed in the shed
And piled high will be the green hay.
When Summer is ended the silo and stack
The shivering cattle will need,
The sturdy farm horses attention will lack
And them will he stable and feed.
But all through the year he must ever depend
On rain from above for his crop,
And at times when it does not his labor [sic] attend
For weeks and months never a drop,
When beholds he at length every dam overflow
And fields looking verdant again,
Then only the light-hearted farmer can know
The joy on the farm after rain!

body.p: Melrose Farm, Gregra. Gregra. A small settlement in the vicinity of Molong, New South Wales, around 300 kilometres inland from Sydney.
